newsitem.title: UK: Daimler takes first step out of '95 financial hole.
newsitem.headline: Daimler takes first step out of '95 financial hole.

text.p: Germany's largest industrial conglomorate, Daimler-Benz AG, took its first step toward lasting profits on Thursday, announcing a rebound in first half earnings after record high losses last year.
Daimler, much criticised for last year's 5.7 billion mark loss, said net profits in the first six months of the 1996 climbed to 782 million marks from a 1.6 billion mark loss for first half of 1995.

Speaking at a press conference, management board chairman Juergen Schrempp said first-half sales climbed 1.3 percent to 49.07 billion marks as operating profit swung to a 827 million mark profit from a 613 million mark loss.
For the second half of 1996 Daimler said it expects a ongoing positive developments, but Schrempp said further work was needed to increase profits.

"So let there be no mistake. We have only just begun," Schrempp said. "Our goal remains that each business unit will achieve a return that is among the top of the world class companies in each sector where we compete."
Schrempp hinted the results may enable the company the pay a dividend this year after not paying a dividend in 1995. "We will go back to discuss dividends," he said.
The net profit result was near the high end of analysts' expectations.

The profit figures were exclusively made according to U.S. GAAP accounting rules for the first time in Daimler's history, in a move designed to make the company more appealing to international investors.

The profit rise was led by the group's flagship unit, car and truck maker Mercedes-Benz AG. Mercedes, benefitting from a stronger dollar and booming sales of its E-Class model posted an 2.8 percent rise in operating profit to 1.4 billion marks.
"Mercedes is now the most profitable automobile manufacturer in the world on a per unit basis and we intend to keep it that way," Schrempp said.
Daimler-Benz Aerospace (DASA), in the midst of a massive cost cutting campaign, showed an operating loss of 677 million marks.
This loss is smaller than the first-half 1995 operating loss of 1.62 billion marks however.

Schrempp restated his belief that DASA will reach the break- even point by 1998, saying he was encouraged by overall growth in the global aircraft industry and a record inflow of Airbus orders. DASA is a major partner in the Airbus Industrie consortium.
Daimler-Benz InterServices (debis), the financial and services division, saw operating profits climb to 212 million marks from 156 million marks in the year earlier period.

Daimler-Benz, Germany's largest conglomorate, was pushed deep into the red last year as it undertook a massive reorganisation aimed to returning to its transporation roots, abandoning dreams to become an integrated technology company.
Meanwhile Daimler shares, which had been climbing in anticipation of strong numbers over the last few days, slipped seven pfennigs to 81.25 marks on profit-taking, traders said.
In 1995, Daimler took one-off charges of 3.9 billion marks including a 2.3 billion mark write down of Dutch aircraft maker Fokker NV and 1.6 billion marks for streamlining of its AEG unit.

Schrempp said Daimler had cut the number of business units in the group's portfolio to 25 from 35 since last May. "The earnings potential for the steamlined portfolio has increased substantially," he said.
